G.L. c. 212, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u0.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, because the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000, exclusive of interest and costs, or, alternatively, because Plaintiff elects to file in the Superior Court as permitted by Massachusetts law.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Hampden County under G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2 because the events and occurrences giving rise to this action took place in Hampden County, Massachusetts, specifically at 123 Elm Street, Springfield, MA, and because both Plaintiff and Defendant reside in Hampden County.

G.L. c. 223A, \u00a7 2.proposition: This Court has personal jurisdiction over Defendant under G.L. c. 223A, § 2 because Defendant is domiciled in Massachusetts and the cause of action arises from acts and omissions occurring within the Commonwealth.

*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u201.proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, every person has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid causing foreseeable harm to others. See, e.g., *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 147–48 (2006); *Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mass. 47, 51 (1983); *Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2000).
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u201.support_reasoning: The court expressly articulates a general Massachusetts tort principle that every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others, conditioned on foreseeability. It cites Restatement (Second) of Torts § 302 and explains that a defendant owes a duty of care to all persons foreseeably endangered by their conduct, which matches the claimed proposition about Massachusetts common-law duty of reasonable care to avoid foreseeable harm.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u201.relevant_excerpt: “We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’ See Remy v. MacDonald, supra at 677, citing Restatement (Second) Torts § 302 comment a (1965). A precondition to this duty is, of course, that the risk of harm to another be recognizable or foreseeable to the actor. … Consequently, with some important exceptions, ‘a defendant owes a duty of care to all persons who are foreseeably endangered by his conduct.’”

*Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mas.proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, every person has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid causing foreseeable harm to others. See, e.g., *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 147–48 (2006); *Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mass. 47, 51 (1983); *Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2000).
*Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mas.support_reasoning: The quoted text is a dissent focused narrowly on proximate cause and foreseeability in the specific context of campus security and rape. It does not articulate or reaffirm the broad Massachusetts common-law duty that "every person has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid causing foreseeable harm to others." That more general duty may be discussed in the *majority* opinion of Mullins, but it does not appear in this excerpted dissent, so this specific text does not support the proposition as cited.
*Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mas.relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff had the burden of proving that the defendant[] took a risk with respect to the plaintiff�19s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk.�1d Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 330 (1982). Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454 (1969).

*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696.proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, every person has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid causing foreseeable harm to others. See, e.g., *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 147–48 (2006); *Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mass. 47, 51 (1983); *Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2000).
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696.support_reasoning: The opinion in Glidden is focused on whether the plaintiffs produced sufficient evidence of causation to survive summary judgment on their negligence and statutory claims. The court explicitly declines to decide whether the defendant owed a duty of care at all, and it does not articulate any general Massachusetts common-law principle that every person has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid causing foreseeable harm. Thus, it does not support the broad duty proposition for which it is cited.
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696.relevant_excerpt: The motion judge found that the plaintiffs had not shown the requisite control necessary to impose a duty on the defendant. Because the plaintiffs have failed to meet their burden on the issue of causation, we need not decide whether they presented sufficient evidence to show that the defendant owed a duty of care to them sufficient to survive the defendant’s motion for summary judgment.

*Yee v. Mass. State Police*, 481 Mass. 2.proposition: This duty of reasonable care applies to the maintenance, storage, and control of one’s property where it may foreseeably create a risk of harm to others. See *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. at 147–49 (duty regarding dangerous instrumentalities on property); *Yee v. Mass. State Police*, 481 Mass. 290, 297 (2019).
*Yee v. Mass. State Police*, 481 Mass. 2.support_reasoning: Yee v. Mass. State Police is an employment discrimination case under G.L. c. 151B dealing with what constitutes an “adverse employment action” in the context of denial of a lateral transfer and lost overtime opportunities. It does not address tort duties, reasonable care, or the maintenance, storage, or control of property or dangerous instrumentalities. The proposition concerns negligence and duty of care regarding property, which is outside the subject matter and holding of Yee, so the case does not support that proposition.
*Yee v. Mass. State Police*, 481 Mass. 2.relevant_excerpt: “We thus conclude that where an employee can show that there are material differences between two positions in the opportunity for compensation, or in the terms, conditions, or privileges of employment, the failure to grant a lateral transfer to the preferred position may constitute an adverse employment action under c. 151B.”

*Morgan v. Lalumiere*, 22 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Defendant further owed Plaintiff a duty to act reasonably once put on actual notice that the unsecured ladder created a specific, foreseeable risk of falling and damaging Plaintiff’s vehicle or otherwise causing harm. See *Jupin*, 447 Mass. at 148–49 (duty informed by foreseeable risk and notice); *Morgan v. Lalumiere*, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 262, 267–68 (1986).
*Morgan v. Lalumiere*, 22 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: Morgan v. Lalumiere is a pedestrian–motorist negligence and comparative fault case. It discusses the general definition of negligence, the reasonable person standard, burden of proof, and comparative negligence instructions, but it does not involve an unsecured ladder, property damage to a vehicle, or a defendant’s duty upon receiving actual notice of a specific, foreseeable risk. The opinion does not analyze a change in duty triggered by notice of a particular hazard, so it does not support the proposition for which it is cited.
*Morgan v. Lalumiere*, 22 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Negligence is the failure to exercise that degree of care which a reasonable person would exercise in the circumstances. Of course, a judge may elaborate upon that definition so long as what he says is consistent with the correct definition of negligence. Without at least some minimal reference to the reasonable person standard and to the attendant circumstances, however, an instruction does not adequately convey the meaning of negligence.” (22 Mass. App. Ct. at 267)

*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.raw_text: *Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc.*, 423 Mass. 637, 639–40 (1996)
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.proposition: The risk that a tall, unsecured ladder could be knocked over by wind and fall onto a nearby vehicle was a natural, probable, and foreseeable consequence of Defendant’s conduct, and thus within the scope of the risk that made Defendant’s conduct negligent. See *Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc.*, 423 Mass. 637, 639–40 (1996); *Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 376 Mass. 101, 105 (1978).
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.support_reasoning: This concurrence explicitly agrees with the majority that the plaintiff’s injuries were not within the reasonably foreseeable risk created by Lombardo’s negligence. It does not state or imply that a risk like a tall, unsecured ladder being blown over onto a nearby vehicle is a natural, probable, and foreseeable consequence within the scope of the defendant’s negligence; rather, it affirms the opposite as to the facts of Poskus. Thus, the case as quoted does not support the proposition asserted.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.relevant_excerpt: “I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiff[’]s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641.”

*Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 376 Mass.proposition: The risk that a tall, unsecured ladder could be knocked over by wind and fall onto a nearby vehicle was a natural, probable, and foreseeable consequence of Defendant’s conduct, and thus within the scope of the risk that made Defendant’s conduct negligent. See *Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc.*, 423 Mass. 637, 639–40 (1996); *Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 376 Mass. 101, 105 (1978).
*Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 376 Mass.support_reasoning: Jesionek concerns whether the negligent failure to secure a dangerous instrumentality (a forklift with keys left in it) made it reasonably foreseeable that an intoxicated seaman would operate it and injure a pedestrian—i.e., classic third‑party misuse/proximate cause analysis. It does not address ladders, wind, or objects being blown over, nor does it involve property damage to a nearby vehicle. While it supports the broader foreseeability/scope‑of‑risk principle later articulated in Poskus, citing Jesionek specifically for the proposition about a ladder being blown by wind onto a car is not accurate or on‑point.
*Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 376 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “Under the facts of this case the jury would have been warranted in concluding that the actions of the seaman were foreseeable… It was thus reasonably foreseeable that the forklift, when left unsecured with the keys in the ignition on premises which were solely under the authority’s control, would be operated by unauthorized persons, including inebriated seamen… It was also reasonably foreseeable… that unauthorized operation would likely cause harm to persons known to pass through the area… Consequently, a jury could have found that the plaintiff’s injury was caused by a negligent act for which the authority was responsible.”

*Banaghan v. Dewey*, 340 Mass. 73, 80 (1.proposition: Defendant’s conduct and omissions, as described above, constitute a failure to act with the ordinary care that a reasonably prudent person would exercise under the circumstances, and therefore amount to negligence under Massachusetts law. See *Jupin*, 447 Mass. at 147–49; *Banaghan v. Dewey*, 340 Mass. 73, 80 (1959).
*Banaghan v. Dewey*, 340 Mass. 73, 80 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely frames liability in negligence terms: Bay State Elevator’s and the trustees’ liability turns on whether they used reasonable care in maintaining and inspecting the elevator, and the court holds there was ‘ample evidence’ of negligent inspection and maintenance. The court explains the duty to keep the elevator in a safe condition, the failure to discover and correct obvious mechanical defects, and affirms that such failures constitute negligence to foreseeable users. That directly supports the general Massachusetts principle that failure to exercise ordinary care under the circumstances amounts to negligence.
*Banaghan v. Dewey*, 340 Mass. 73, 80 (1.relevant_excerpt: “Here the jury could have found that the elevator company had contracted with the trustees, at least to inspect the elevator, and at most to maintain it in ‘A‑1 safe condition.’ … The apparatus had been installed, repaired, and maintained by the defendant over a period of years, and there was ample evidence, which we need not repeat, of its negligence in inspecting and maintaining the elevator. The plaintiffs, tenants in the building and the elevator operator, were unquestionably within the class of persons likely to be injured by its negligence.”

*Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 M.raw_text: *Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 Mass. 790, 794–96 (1987)
*Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 M.proposition: But for Defendant’s failure to secure or relocate the ladder, the ladder would not have fallen onto Plaintiff’s vehicle and Plaintiff would not have suffered the property damage and economic losses described herein. See *Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 Mass. 790, 794–96 (1987) (causation standard); *McLaughlin v. Bernstein*, 356 Mass. 219, 226 (1969).
*Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 M.case_name: Solimene v. B. GRAUEL & CO., KG
*Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 M.support_reasoning: The proposition uses Solimene for the general causation standard (“but for” causation and need not prove the exact mechanism), not for the specific ladder fact pattern. In Solimene, the SJC states that a plaintiff need not show the exact way an accident happened and that causation is satisfied if the plaintiff proves a greater probability that the harm was due to causes for which defendant is responsible. That aligns with the proposition’s use of Solimene as general authority on causation, especially when paired with McLaughlin v. Bernstein.
*Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 M.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff has the burden to show that Grauel’s negligence caused her injury. The plaintiff may meet that burden by presenting two possible theories of defect to the jury. ‘There is no requirement of law that the plaintiff point out the exact way an accident happens.’ McLaughlin v. Bernstein, 356 Mass. 219, 226 (1969). … The plaintiff sustained her burden by proving that there was a greater probability that the harm which occurred was due to causes for which Grauel was responsible.”

*McLaughlin v. Bernstein*, 356 Mass. 219.proposition: But for Defendant’s failure to secure or relocate the ladder, the ladder would not have fallen onto Plaintiff’s vehicle and Plaintiff would not have suffered the property damage and economic losses described herein. See *Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 Mass. 790, 794–96 (1987) (causation standard); *McLaughlin v. Bernstein*, 356 Mass. 219, 226 (1969).
*McLaughlin v. Bernstein*, 356 Mass. 219.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns factual or “but for” causation. McLaughlin expressly states that the plaintiff need only show that the harm was more likely caused by the defendant’s negligence than by any other cause, and that the plaintiff need not prove the exact mechanism of the accident. That is a clear articulation of the Massachusetts causation standard, which is consistent with using the case to support a but-for causation allegation about the ladder falling and causing property damage.
*McLaughlin v. Bernstein*, 356 Mass. 219.relevant_excerpt: “Either one of these conditions could be found to be a probable cause for the escape of the gas and both reasonably excluded the likelihood of other causes. … There is no requirement of law that the plaintiff point out the exact way an accident happens. The plaintiff sustained her burden if she proved that there was greater likelihood or probability that the harm complained of was due to causes for which the defendant was responsible than from any other cause.”

*Wallace v. Ludwig*, 292 Mass. 251, 256.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a negligent tortfeasor is liable for all damages that are the natural and probable consequence of the wrongful act. See *Wallace v. Ludwig*, 292 Mass. 251, 256 (1935); *Vosburgh v. Med. Prof. Ins. Ass’n*, 376 Mass. 757, 766 (1978).
*Wallace v. Ludwig*, 292 Mass. 251, 256.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely discusses proximate cause and expressly adopts a “natural and probable connection” standard when describing the causal link between the wrongful act and the injurious consequence. It reiterates earlier Massachusetts precedent that liability extends where there is a natural and probable connection between the defendant’s negligent act and the resulting harm, and then applies that principle to hold the defendant potentially liable for all damages flowing through that continuous causal sequence, including the fatal infection.
*Wallace v. Ludwig*, 292 Mass. 251, 256.relevant_excerpt: “In McDonald v. Snelling, 14 Allen, 290, 296, it was said: ‘the mere circumstance that there have intervened, between the wrongful cause and the injurious consequence, acts produced by the volition of animals or of human beings, does not necessarily make the result so remote that no action can be maintained. The test is to be found, not in the number of intervening events or agents, but in their character, and in the natural and probable connection between the wrong done and the injurious consequence.’ … It is settled that … the defendant may be liable for all the consequences.”

*Vosburgh v. Med. Prof. Ins. Ass\u2019n*.raw_text: *Vosburgh v. Med. Prof. Ins. Ass’n*, 376 Mass. 757, 766 (1978)
*Vosburgh v. Med. Prof. Ins. Ass\u2019n*.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a negligent tortfeasor is liable for all damages that are the natural and probable consequence of the wrongful act. See *Wallace v. Ludwig*, 292 Mass. 251, 256 (1935); *Vosburgh v. Med. Prof. Ins. Ass’n*, 376 Mass. 757, 766 (1978).
*Vosburgh v. Med. Prof. Ins. Ass\u2019n*.case_name: Loranger Construction Corp. v. E. F. Hauserman Co.
*Vosburgh v. Med. Prof. Ins. Ass\u2019n*.support_reasoning: The quoted portions of Vosburgh concern offer, acceptance, consideration, and reliance in a subcontract-bidding/promissory-estoppel context. They do not discuss the scope of damages, proximate cause, or the rule that a negligent tortfeasor is liable for all damages that are the natural and probable consequence of the wrongful act. Thus, this opinion does not provide authority for the tort damages proposition stated; Wallace v. Ludwig may, but Vosburgh (at least at the cited pages) does not.
*Vosburgh v. Med. Prof. Ins. Ass\u2019n*.relevant_excerpt: "Several other matters argued by the defendant to the Appeals Court are discussed in the opinion of that court: unreasonable delay by the plaintiff in notifying the defendant that it was to be the subcontractor, 'bid shopping' by the plaintiff, and application of the Statute of Frauds... The Appeals Court held that they did not bar recovery based on reliance, and they have no more force to bar recovery based on bargain plus reliance."

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: To the extent any comparative negligence is argued, Massachusetts follows a modified comparative negligence rule under G.L. c. 231, § 85, permitting Plaintiff to recover so long as Plaintiff’s negligence, if any, is not greater than the total negligence of Defendant. Plaintiff denies any negligence and alleges that Defendant’s negligence was the sole proximate cause of the harm.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover from Defendant the full amount of his property damage and related economic losses, together with statutory interest, costs, and such further relief as the Court deems just and proper. See G.L. c. 231, § 6B (prejudgment interest in tort actions).

G.L. c. 223 and c. 223A.proposition: Plaintiff’s claim is governed by Massachusetts negligence law, including, without limitation: a. G.L. c. 231, § 85 (comparative negligence); b. G.L. c. 231, § 6B (prejudgment interest in tort actions); c. G.L. c. 212, § 4 (jurisdiction of the Superior Court); d. G.L. c. 223 and c. 223A (venue and personal jurisdiction); and e. Common-law negligence principles as articulated in *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141 (2006); *Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mass. 47 (1983); *Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694 (2000); *Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc.*, 423 Mass. 637 (1996); *Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 376 Mass. 101 (1978); *Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 Mass. 790 (1987); *Wallace v. Ludwig*, 292 Mass. 251 (1935); *Morgan v. Lalumiere*, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 262 (1986); *Banaghan v. Dewey*, 340 Mass. 73 (1959); and related authorities.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60.proposition: Plaintiff hereby demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable as of right under the Constitution and laws of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts. See Mass. R. Civ. P. 38; G.L. c. 231, § 60.
